You know that one guy that logs into the FPS and just kills everyone by himself? So you eventually just have to leave the server because no one can kill him and things are getting hostile since it's no fun for anyone but him and now people are raging about hacks that may or may not exist?

Well now you can be that guy!
________________________________________

Just an add on for the top reviews saying the game is too short, I spent 2-3 hours on the story, I've spent 7-8 hours so far on the modes I unlocked after beating story and I've still not gotten to unlocking all the endless arenas or challanges. So I'm just going to respectfully disagree with the price not being worth it.

The BULK of the game and its unlockables appears to be after you beat the story line.

________________________________________

Lots of arguments going on about this game, since I've somehow ended up as a top review I'll go ahead and expand further on why I think the game is worth the price with things I've said in the comments.

The story is just a  prelude to the meat of the game, a fabric to wrap the metagame of the arena/arcade shooter in. Why you're doing this seemingly pointless task of killing red guys, the sort of world you're fighting in, etc.

The story itself doesn't flat out tell you much either, even after you beat it you still have to piece things together by explore the menus, hidden features, chat logs, and there's also secrets and hidden terminals on each level of the campaign that let you access more lore/chat logs... something to go back and find after you've beaten them once.

But in the end much like in a fighting game you're really just here for the mechanics anyway, so buy it for that and you shouldn't be disappointed.

reviewText:
SUPERHOT is an FPS puzzle game where time moves when you do (which is by the way not entirely true, because even if you do not move - time does advance very slowly).
It's really that simple - move carefully, dodge bullets, plan your moves and kill red guys.

By now you'd probably already read a bunch of reviews that smacked the game for short story.
That's totally true - it took me about 1.5h to beat the campaign.
But in my opinion story is nothing more than a tutorial (and a nifty William Gibson-esque cyberpunk-y explanation of what's going on).
The cool stuff starts with challenges and replaying the same 34 levels with different rulesets.

And here's the main question - are you the person that enjoys the story or a person that like game mechanics and gameplay?
If you are into stories, then I'd suggest waiting until this game is discounted. 10$ or sounds about right for the story only.
But if you like mechanics - then grab this game right now, it's bloody amazing.

Especially awesome moments of slicing bullets, changing bodies and catching your own weapon mid-air included.
Developers joked about it in-game, but I'll say it anyway - It's the most innovative shooter I've played in years.
And definitely one of my favourite games of 2016.

If you need more info, you can watch me play some levels and compare different rulesets on using same level here:
https://youtu.be/qwg9XKPEdY4

reviewText:
Superhot is a first person shooter with a very interesting and satisfying mechanic
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=xP5pOyi5nxU
The main focus of Superhot, is that time only moves when you move. Fortunately, the game constantly keeps things fresh, so the time mechanic doesn't feel gimmicky or boring.

You and you enemies both die with one bullet, which makes things quite intense, and prevents the time thing from being too overpowered.
The game gives you a wide range of moves to make you feel like a badass. You may throw your gun or any random object like a statue at an enemy to temporarily stun them. In doing so, they will also drop their weapon. That gives you a chance to take the weapon and kill opponents, or just beat them to death while they're vulnerable.

There's a decent variety when it comes to weapons. Katanas, pistols and shotguns are just a few. The great thing is if you can use them, be sure that they can be used against you.

The game is very stylized. Enemies shatter into small crystal-like pieces, and text flashes on the screen as if you're playing an interactive trailer. There's no HUD, so even when you run out of ammo, your only indication is AFTER you have gotten ready for a shot, and pulled the trigger. The text will tell you you're out, and you have to discard the gun. It all makes for some really intense fights.

The game can actually be quite slow-paced at times. Almost like a strategy or puzzle game. You need to minimize your movements to avoid forwarding time much, or zig-zag dodge bullets.

At the end of every level, you have a chance to save a replay in case you did something cool.

There's actually quite an interesting story that I don't want to go into, because it's best unspoiled. Don't expect a focus on story, but it's nice that it's there.

The main game was quite short. Took me about 2 hours to beat, but there are a lot of challenges that increase replay value for you, and an endless mode where you can put your skills to the test. The gameplay is satisfying enough to make me want to go through and complete those.

Overall, it's such an awesome game. It's incredibly satisfying, and makes you feel like an action hero. If you like the look of it, then you have to play this game, I've never seen anything like it before.

Recommended!

There are a few flaws and an intimidating price tag, but it's worth your time if you get it on sale.

Graphics
The visuals have gotten mixed reception, but I'm personally a fan of the art style here. It's simple without feeling lazy, like many other indie games when it comes to their graphics. Plus, I can't help but watch the red guys as they crumple to the ground after they were killed. It makes every kill feel ten times more satisfying. Overall, the art style is simple in a good way.

Gameplay

Yes, the main story IS really short, but I'll get in depth with that in the Replayability" section of my review. The gameplay mechanics are unique and really creative. reviewText:
First of all and perhaps most importantly - this game is extremely fun.  Certainly the most innovative shooter I've played for quite some time. It's on the level of Portal with it's ingenuity. You will enjoy the time mechanics. I have nothing negative to say about the gameplay - it's superb.

Nearly as important, though, is how depressingly short the game is. I beat it in 1.4 hours with a moderate amount of failure and taking the time to enjoy the story.  In an age where we buy games that can take hundreds of hours to complete - a game that only takes 1.4 is simply far too short.  It's not worth the price.  I didn't get $25 worth of play from this game, because it isn't there.  The game ends just as you fall in love with it.  It's an abrupt relationship.

This should be your first buy during the next big steam sale. $5-10 would be perfect.  Put it on your wishlist and don't forget about it, but don't buy it right now.  It's not worth your $25.   If it was a proper length then I'd pay $60 for it because the idea is innovative and fresh.   But 1.4 hours is not even close to enough content to justify the price.

reviewText:
I will update the review as I find more

SUPERHOT
SUPERHOT is a game that is addicting and fun as time moves when you do. I will add a TL;DR at the end

Gameplay
SUPERHOT has an amazing game mechanic where when you move time moves making every single motion count. It‚Äôs a very fun game but had a short campaign mode. In the game you are given superhot.exe by a friend and are told to try it out, from the beginning it is just killing random red enemies as you control time and allow yourself be look like you came out of an action movie where you are a special agent or something along those lines. As you head further there is a plot and it darkens quickly. There are also little side games and such you can access if you are bored or listen to a game generated chatroom (because why join one yourself). The levels are fun and interesting with levels of difficulty trying to dodge enemies and bullets from all angles. The main storyline however feels short and beatable after a not so long period of time. However there is also an endless mode, mini games, and challenges.

Graphics/Sound
So SUPERHOT‚Äôs graphics are pretty basic but with the type of gameplay it contains it feels as if you shatter glass figures when you destroy the red enemies adding a special kind of satisfaction. The sound is very useful for being able to tell if you are being shot from behind or anywhere and has saved me a few times. I love the polish song at the credits, did not even notice the the developers were polish untill I recognized some of the last names and the song.

Pros/Cons
Pros

+ Amazing gameplay mechanic
+ Replays of levels once beaten
+ Satisfyingly violent
+ Addictive
+ Other modes and mini games
+ Full controller support

Cons

- Relatively short campaign/story
- Pretty simple story

Suggestions
Here are some suggestions I feel would improve the game

- Expansion to campaign/story
- Future ability to design levels
- More weapons

Final Thoughts
SUPERHOT has completely brought something new and I loved it. It felt amazing to have bullets simply flow right past me as I dodged, punched the guy, took his gun, and shot him and 3 other guys. It‚Äôs a shame how short the main story is but an amazingly impressive title nonetheless. I cannot however judge this game as not being good enough for how long it's taken because I was not a part of that process like some were so I am just evaluating SUPERHOT for itself.

I would definitely say that as a game, as a mechanic it has an ace in the hole even though it is rather short

SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT

TL;DR
SUPERHOT has been completely revolutionized through its game mechanic as time moves with you. It also contains alternate modes and mini games. Overall currently it is a short but sweet game with a shorter campaign but amazing and addicting gameplay.

reviewText:
So, first of all, yes, story mode took me around 2,5 hours to complete. That's fairly short for that price, so if you're only interested in that, then it may not be worth your money. But, after spending twice as that, for me it has much more to offer after finishing the story.  There are various challenges and endless modes, both are really fun to do and unlock progressively - the more you play and beat the target score/time/pass the level, the more content you have. This so far keeps me entertained and still makes me play more and improve. For 15 euro I paid for this game, I think I already got my money worth by those 5 hours spent. This is a long review, so I will include a short summary just at the end of it as TL;DR version.

Gameplay-wise, this is not your everyday shooter. As you may already know from trailers, time only moves when you move (or generally, perform any action). Some of the story levels felt more like a puzzle - getting the spawn patterns right, knowing which corner to watch for, avoiding those nasty gunshots from ever hitting you. The more you play, the more game mechanics you discover. At very first, I did not know that you can have your time slowed while jumping, but this apparently is a thing and can help with avoiding bullets a lot while still closing the gap to any weapons you need. Melee weapons are a blast, with katana being the strongest (in my opinion) - I personally like to throw it for instakills, slice red guys with almost no hit delay whatsoever (with gunshots, most of guns have a delay between shots to make sure you just don't spam the trigger). I also saw katana blocking bullets, but so far I mostly failed with that one by destroying a weapon I wanted to grab by accidentally throwing katana into it (whoops !). AI is spot-on, although it just shoots in your general direction and may cause some friendly fire on the way, but I find it more as a feature than a flaw.

It's hard to say more about gameplay  without spoiling too much for the player, so let's get to visuals and performance, both are really great. I'm running the game on fairly low-spec laptop (with Geforce 630m crippling it the most) in 1024x768, and manage to mantain 30fps+ at most moments, while having the graphics at low quality, but that only impacts the shadow quality and Anti-Aliasing, and game still looks great with artstyle of mostly white and red colours used. Just beware, as the game seems to be built with Unity engine, there are some issues with that, which are engine-specific - it seems like changing resolution to one with non-native aspect ratio (4:3, 5:4 etc. if you're running a 16:9 monitor), makes it so there are black borders on the side that are catching any Steam in-game elements to stay in there even if they are not visible, and also making the video smaller overall. I could get used to this, but I figure some people may not, so just be aware of this.

SUMMARY
-great, innovative gameplay (time moves only when you move, kind of player-centred)
-flashy, white and red artstyle with text comments about what's going on flashing in front of gameplay (may be obstructive at times, but overall it's spot on IMO), a small epilepsy warning here, as this text is the most flashy" element in the game.
-just OK sound
recommended:
nothing that could break game experience
-very good performance with some Unity engine-specific issues here and there
-big replay value with challenges and endless modes

Is it worth the money ? If you considered all the stuff mentioned here and still want to just finish story mode and be done with it

reviewText:
SUPERHOT is a first person time manipulation game, releasing in February 2016, developed and published by SUPERHOT Team.

The game play is what makes SUPERHOT, what it is. You play from a first person perspective as you navigate and complete challenges and levels through the single player modes. How you progress will be dictated on how well you are able to manipulate time to your advantage. Time only progresses when you move your character, whether it be simply moving your camera angel, or by taking a step forward, time will go on. As soon as you stop, time will freeze, allowing you to plot your next move accordingly. Throughout the game you will gain access to different weapons in the form of shotguns, machine guns and samurai swords. These all play key parts in the levels you find them and are often the key to completion.  Whilst most levels are actually pretty short in terms of the content available, playing them out in the slowed down time frame can mean you are sometimes acting out the scene for up to five minutes. Once you complete the level by eliminating all of the enemies, you will get to watch back the scene in full speed, allowing you to marvel at the spectacle you have just created; most of the time, it is something of pure beauty to watch as your character glides through the level chopping off heads, getting headshots, and perfectly catching enemies off guard.

Graphically, SUPERHOT is very clean, almost medical like art style. The whites, blacks and reds all contrast well against each other. The game runs on the Unity engine so the fidelity of the animations, and character models are all really high quality, with very high production values found right the way through the audio side of the game with top notch narration and sound effects.

This game is hard, but you soon get to grips with the game play and you can often conquer most levels after a handful of attempts of just correcting your own mistakes. I personally really enjoyed the trial and error aspect of this game, as the reset time for each failure was quick and snappy, allowing you to get straight back into the action after messing up. On top of the game‚Äô s story mode, SUPERHOT, also includes an endless mode ‚Äì this is where you have literally an endless amount of enemies come at you. We also have a challenge mode that will basically replay the single player missions but give you additional certain rules and hurdles to overcome at the same time too.

I managed to finish the single player story mode to SUPERHOT in just under two hours, which was a little short for my liking, but where you will get the most mileage and replay value out of SUPERHOT, is the challenge mode and endless mode; you will be able to get countless hours of entertainment out of both of these game modes if you enjoy the gameplay enough. I would have liked to see a longer story mode, but we can‚Äôt have everything I guess.

SUPERHOT is definitely one of the surprises to come out of 2016. It may be priced a little on the high end given the short story mode, but it can be almost made up by the two extra modes. I‚Äôd personally recommend the game even at the regular price of ¬£17.99. The game also has VR support which will just be amazing to see how it plays out on that format.

Tom's Score Card
1) Stay away
2) Not Recommended
3) Only recommended when on sale
4) Recommended
5) Highly recommended
6) This is a must play

If you found this review helpful, please give it a thumbs up. If you would also like to follow my reviews more easily, be sure to join my group by clicking here and checking out the TeamTom Review site[teamtomreviews.co.uk]

reviewText:
The game is good. It's gameplay is probably the most solid it'll ever get and it got a graphical upgrade. If you liked the prototype and just wanted more levels, then this is the game for you. However for me, it felt like 2.5 years wasn't worth the wait.

1) The gameplay can get repetitive. While anyone will feel like a badass playing this, it can wear off a bit as the guns are just the same 3 types: pistol, smg, shotgun. Melee weapons are pretty much the same except for the katana.

2) The story is WAY too meta. It's a game about playing a game and it tries to make you feel like your being sucked in literally. Plus, the ending is a bit indulgent.

All in all, if you just wanted more levels, weapons, and a graphical upgrade, that's fine. This is a game.

However, if you were expecting something more for waiting 2.5 years, you might be dissapointed. To me, it felt a bit like the developers spent too much time polishing.

It's a good game, just not the game I was expecting.

reviewText:
Superhot is a really innovative new shooter that does a lot to immerse you in the world it creates around itself. It is extremely fun to play around with, and can certainly be a game you can play with friends to see who can do the coolest things, but $25 is a bit too much for what is being bought.

For one, Superhot's main story is only about 2 hours long. Even with a dozen retries on some levels, I still completed it in under 2 hours. That is quite ridiculous, as the replayable content doesn't go very far after that either. The only modes available following the main story are Endless Mode and some Challenge modes. You can probably squeeze a few extra hours out of those if you're in love with the game, but other than that... you won't be playing this for long, and as such, you definitely won't want to cough up $25 for a 3-4 hour experience in a video game.

Is Superhot worth playing? Yes. Like I said, it is exhilarating to play. It's an experience I've never had before, and would love to have again in a different aesthetic. Maybe a more realistic one. If you can buy Superhot on sale, go for it. But at it's current asking price, I just can't recommend the title.

reviewText:
This was not a decision I made lightly. It's a bit of a shame that Steam reviews only have a thumbs up or thumbs down, not any sort of in-between score.
I expect that fans of the game will downvote the hell out of this review for not recommending it.

Truth is I'm a huge fan of this game. Despite a couple technical hiccups (which may not be actual bugs, given the nature of the game), the game is ridiculously fun and stylish as hell. Though SUPERHOT has really only one gameplay gimmick, it never grew stale. Killing a room full of red guys in impossible situations never got boring, and the game's narrative actually kept me very engaged.

Since time only moves when you do, the game feels very far away from any other first person shooter made before it. It's impossible to run-and-gun, you need to carefully plan your steps to dodge deadly projectiles, while also aiming carefully and lining up those perfect shots; with so little ammo, you can't afford to be careless. It's the freshest breath of air an FPS fan has been able to inhale for the last long while.

So why am I not recommending this incredible game?

The price.


I've defended games like Jazzpunk and McPixel, even Undertale, when faced with the criticism of a game being too short. I truly believe it's about the experience. But SUPERHOT has pushed my limit.
$35 Canadian dollars for a game you can potentially beat in a few hours?
It's not quite worth it.

SUPERHOT is amazing. But $35 is a very steep price for a quick game. I suppose there is replay value in the Endless Mode, trying to do sections more efficiently, and trying to uncover the game's secrets. But really, as excellent and fun as it may be, there is no variation in gameplay.

Tons of AAA titles boast campaigns that barely register 6 hours and they cost twice as much, I know this. But, having paid a much smaller price for games I felt carried more weight, I still don't think SUPERHOT has a justifiable price.
If it came down in a sale or something I'd push this game onto every person within reach and earshot of me.


SUPERHOT is an incredibly creative and well-crafted game.
It just costs too much right now.

reviewText:
TL;DR: NOT RECOMMENDED, not worth 25$ at the time this review was posted. Wait for 15$ or preferably less on a sale.

Superhot, as a game concept, is really good. A first person shooter where time only passes when you move. This trick lets you weave in and out of enemies and bullets, letting you do a lot of movements and actions that let you feel like a pro stuntman. A small variety of weapons and throwable objects give you plenty of options to choose when dealing with oncoming bullets. Do you jump and dodge? Take cover? Do you block the bullet with an object? Cause the enemy to do friendly fire? You are free to deal with situations as you see fit, so you can express a lot of your personal style in your actions. A well integrated replay feature lets you share your choices with the world.

If that was all that were in the game, similar to the 2013 prototype, along with plenty of levels and a point beyond just killing red dudes"

reviewText:
I can't recommend it or not. The core gameplay is great, but there are a lot of problems. If you like the demo and would like to play with variations on it on ~25 levels, go for it. An extra gameplay mechanic gets chucked in halfway to spice things up a little.

It's a lot like Portal in that it's a small, short puzzlish game with an excellent, original atmosphere and style, but it's nowhere near as polished.
Story is compelling and fun, but only 2 hours long. Half of the challenge modes are good, half are garbage, there's about 12 in total. Endless mode is fun but you don't have any rewards or goals. Time-trial mode is the same. What sealed the deal for me continuing to play was the secret-finding exploration mode.

It's fun to start up and play one or two levels for 5mins.
Add a level editor and proper way to share them and this would be solid gold.

~~~ Here's all the problems that should be easily fixed ~~~

Endless modes and time-trial modes are lack-luster; it doesn't compare scores against friends or give rankings/grades. Stupidly, the first ~1.5 seconds of in-game time occur with the loading screen still up, so you have to begin blindly to get the best times, not that there is anything motivating you to improve your time past the single goal they give. Endless mode is fun, but the game gives you no milestones to aim for - all of the unlockables (timed endless modes) are unlocked by total kills ever rather than top score.

Irredeemable bugs:
There's a minigame that doesn't stop the music on exiting, leaving it looping over itself and forcing a restart. Some achievements are bugged, including giving me the complete all time trials" achievement when I only did 5 of them. Worst of all

reviewText:
Superhot is an indie first person shooter running on the Unity engine. It has such a novel premise I'm surprised it hasn't been done before.

In this game, time slows down to a near standstill when you stop moving. And progresses forwards when you move and when you fire. The development team implemented this very well. Bullets fly through the air and are very easy to spot among the white level textures. The game has this very Hotline Miami feel to it. You can throw your guns at enemies to stun them, you can throw objects to block bullets, and you can even shoot bullets in midair as they fly towards you. For a game that should feel slow and calculated, it feels very fast paced and rhythmic.

Stylistically the game is very interesting. The UI resembles a DOS based operating system. Enemies resemble low poly characters from old video games. At the same time the environments look very crisp and everything stands out very well. If you're a fan of films like Tron you'll definitely like this game.

However, all that being said the game is not perfect, and it's very hard for me to recommend. For the 25$ asking price there's very little content and you can mostly beat it in a handful of hours. The level design also maintains the same white sterile aesthetic and doesn't have that much variety to it. While the core gameplay is pretty solid it appeals to a certain kind of player. It appeals to the kind of player that wants to play a level over and over to try and achieve a perfect run.

If you're that kind of player I do recommend this game a lot. But to everyone else I'd say wait a little for the dev to either create a level editor or lower the price.

reviewText:
Superhot is possibly the most disappointing game I‚Äôve played so far this year. It‚Äôs got a great premise with it‚Äôs time bending matrix style mechanics, but to be perfectly honest with you that‚Äôs all it‚Äôs got going for it.
Now for those of you unfamiliar with the title, Superhot is a first person shooter where time moves only as you do‚Ä¶ remember those fight sequences in 300‚Ä¶ now imagine them with guns and you‚Äôve got superhot ‚Äì a never before seen melting pot of both strategic and twitch based shooting.

Now of course bullet time isn‚Äôt really a new thing and over the years we‚Äôve been inundated with enough Max Payne and F.E.A.R clones to be sick of the concept. However, it‚Äôs never really had any use beyond doing John Woo‚Äôesque dives to look cool and break up the otherwise monotonous game loop. Heck if you‚Äôre name‚Äôs Dereck and you enjoy filing tax returns you could probably get through Max Payne without using bullet time once.

The difference with superhot is that the games mechanics actually force you to choreograph some really impressive stunts just to stay alive. It‚Äôs a bit like hotline Miami where getting hit once causes instant death forcing the player to make split second decisions to stand a chance in a firefight. Infact it‚Äôs a lot like hotline Miami with throwable objects used to stun enemies and block bullets, and very similar melee and projectile weapons.

The only real difference in terms of gameplay is hotline‚Äôs top down all-seeing perspective compared with Superhot‚Äôs much more limited first person view, a limitation in theory meant to balance out the bullet time‚Ä¶ In practice I‚Äôve been shot in the back countless times by enemies behind me. It feels cheap and annoying and it‚Äôs one of the major problems I have with the gameplay.

It also feels like the dev‚Äôs either didn‚Äôt know or didn‚Äôt care about this problem when they created their replay system, kilstagram. The idea behind it is that, after you‚Äôve cleared each level, you get to watch a replay of you dispatching your enemies in real time which you get the option to upload to various social media sites. You know because all those nightclub photographs you got tagged in weren‚Äôt enough to show people how much fun you were having without them.
Anyway on paper it sounds like a pretty cool idea ‚Äì the chance for you to show off your Wachowskii‚Äôesque bullet time skills but in reality the played back footage looks more like that of a twitchy counterstrike player as you keep glancing behind you to make sure you don‚Äôt get flanked causing the camera to spin back and forth making it headache inducing to watch‚Ä¶ actually that does sound a lot like a wachowskii film.

Aaaand that‚Äôs it‚Ä¶ well at least in terms of mechanics‚Ä¶ and to be honest with you it all feels very lackluster. For all it borrows from Hotline Miami, I kinda wish they‚Äôd taken more. At the moment there simply isn‚Äôt any reward for combos or difficult kills like headshots, there isn‚Äôt even any music in the background which makes it feel more like an early access title than anything else. But I guess that‚Äôs the kind of aesthetic they were going for ‚Äì everything in the game is made up of plain textures with a really minimalist color scheme.  And it also ties in with the story the dev‚Äôs wanted to tell‚Ä¶ that‚Äôs right the dev‚Äôs actually managed to come up with a story to tie all of this together, though as you‚Äôll see it‚Äôs so phoned in and half-arsed it feels more like it‚Äôs there for the sake of having a story.

Remember Pony island? Good Neither does the guy that wrote this drivel.  Instead of being a story within Superhot‚Äôs universe, it‚Äôs a story about playing superhot. You start off the game looking at a dos style operating system when suddenly you get an instant message from a friend sending you a file titled ‚Äúsuperhot.exe‚Äù. After playing a few levels, the system detects you and it pans out exactly as you‚Äôd expect it to be with the system trying to stop the player and the player finding loopholes and backdoor routes to evade the system.  The problem with the narrative is that it does not compliment the gameplay ‚Äì you could replace the shooting segments with Tetris and the story would still work.
It‚Äôs a prime example of what people who like to use big words to sound clever call Ludonarative Dissonance, where the gameplay and story don‚Äôt match and the exposition just feels like a hindrance to the actual meat of the game.
Whilst I can kind of get over the mediocre storyline, the thing I find unforgivable is the 2-hour campaign length. That‚Äôs right, you can beat the game in a single sitting! Now I‚Äôm not saying all short games are bad, in fact titles like Portal have been praised for not overstaying their welcome with their shot length. The problem with Superhot being so short is that instead of leaving me wanting more, I just feel unsatisfied by the finished product.

To rub it in, the dev‚Äôs have had a working prototype since 2013 which featured quite a few of the levels that ended up in the full game, most of which was made in a few days at a game jam. It can‚Äôt be so hard to make a level that the team could only pump out 20 or so short levels in 3 years! Especially with backing and e3 coverage by both Sony and Microsoft. To have the balls to demand 17 quid (that‚Äôs the equivalent of 3 copies of Undertale) for a game that can be beaten in an afternoon is a little bit insulting. Granted there‚Äôs more to it than just the campaign, there‚Äôs also the arena mode where you have to fend off endless waves of enemies which gets boring after about an hour and there‚Äôs the challenge mode where you‚Äôll have to play the campaign meeting certain conditions (for example only using the katana). Like the story, both these additional modes feel last minute and tacked on.

The best analogy I have for the game as a whole is to imagine the first chapter of id software‚Äôs doom being sold full price. Back in its heyday in the 90‚Äôs nobody had ever seen anything like DOOM and I can safely say the gameplay of superhot is just as innovative. However, whilst the game that‚Äôs there is relatively enjoyable, albeit flawed, it just ends before the more interesting experimental stages (like in the 3rd act of doom) get to be shown. Ultimately I can‚Äôt really recommend picking up the game unless it‚Äôs heavily discounted and, to go with the analogy, the game receives a John Romero out of 10. It showed a lot of promise in it‚Äôs early days as a prototype, started getting full of itself at e3 and then ultimately ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• the bed with one fell daikatanaesque swoop.

reviewText:
Imagine if you will:  Wait, what was I talking about?

SUPER
HOT
SUPER
HOT
SUPER...
HOT....

Imagine, if you will, a simulator where everything is in slow motion.  Then imagine that when you move, the rest of the world moves.  Granted, if you don't move at all things are still moving, but very slowly.  So slow, in fact, that you can potentially dodge bullets, cut enemies to shreds before they can move, toss guns into the face of oncoming attackers and pick up their weapon in mid-air and shoot them with it... all before the guy behind them even has a chance to aim at you.  But, take a step without being aware or look around too much, and you'll likely end up getting clobbered from a direction you didn't even know was a threat.

This game is great on so many different levels that it's really hard to cover everything.  I was a kickstarter backer and have played the game on various levels of completion and none of it was ever enough to quench my curiousity about the plot and, of course, the gameplay.

You basically have hundreds of ways to play through each level.  Choose to go at it fisticuffs for some additional challenge or destroy everyone with headshots.  Just about any way you can figure it out, that's going to work.  Except, of course, the ways it won't.  Which, you'll find out later in the game, become pretty linear... brutally so.  However, keeping your wits about you can get you through most levels without even a retry.

And... visit the chatroom (GGchat).  There is more going on there that there appears to be at first... including some hints for different levels.

I definitely recommend this game for anyone that has a computer!

And, don't forget... SUPER HOT SUPER HOT SUPER HOT!

reviewText:
SUPERHOT:
~~~~~~~~~

Sitting down in front of your state of the art terminal (in the eighties, most likely) you are chatting to a friend about this game called, SUPERHOT! To play the game, you will have to download the exe. file and upon launching it, you will be killing SUPERHOT red opponents.

Superhot is a First Person Shooter with a time manipulation mechanism which make this game really fun to play.  You will be able to play a short story mode of approximately 2 hours and 30 minutes. When you successfully complete the story, you will unlock the endless and challenge modes.  The challenge mode is the story mode but you can only use a specific weapon all the way through and the first weapon is the Katana. In the endless mode you have to kill as many opponents as possible before your fall.

I really like the gameplay of SUPERHOT with the time manipulation mechanism, the whitish compact levels and the unmissable red opponents. Sometimes you will be harmed with a gun, shotgun, machine gun, katana, or maybe with nothing but your faithful hands, which can become tricky!  What you have to do is to dismiss all the red combatants to clear the level but remember, they too have the weapons mentioned above. As you spawn, you might or might not see one or several enemies. When you start moving, the enemies will move too, and will start shooting at you straight away. If you are fired upon and stop moving you will see the bullets coming at you in slow motion. In terms of ammunition they have a limitation for all firearms and sometimes the only way to stunt and acquire your opponent‚Äôs weapons is to throw your empty weapon towards them. If left with your bare hands, try to look around for tools or utensils to throw at them instead. On some occasions, you will be able to use the ‚Äúhotswitch‚Äù ability, which is the ability to switch from your body to the enemy in front of you.  To be honest with you, I am very surprised how fast and frustrating some levels are. For me, it was the elevator levels where you have to clear three enemies armed with guns in the lift, with two other guys waiting with shotguns on the other side of the door. That was SUPERHOT AND SUPER HARD!

Graphically the game looks good and the animations are well done. I personally find the story very short but the endless and challenge modes give you good re-playability.  I would have expected more content for the asking price.

Positives:
~~~~~~~

-	Great concept with compact levels
-	Fun game to play
-	Endless and challenge modes
-	Achievements and trading cards

Negatives:
~~~~~~~~

-	Very Short Story mode
-	Needs more content, in my opinion

SUPERHOT is a fun first person shooter in well-designed compact levels.

7.5/10

reviewText:
Please try the prototype for this game before you buy it. It's available for free on the Superhot website, and really is an accurate reflection of the final game. I tried it, and disliked it, but bought the game anyway, thinking maybe the final version would be better.
The hitbox for the player is very misleading, and makes it very difficult to judge where you can move to avoid a bullet. Enemy ai is bland and predictable. The real problem of the game comes in with how enemies spawn. If you have yet to memorize where they'll come from, then when they spawn in already shooting, they WILL kill you.
The game's short length, of around 2 hours + challenges, is perfect for its awful story, but is lackluster for a $20 release. There is little variety in weapons and opportunities during gameplay.
In addition, there may be a small amount of bugs, but it's difficult to tell when the game's presentation is the glitchy style.
If you like the prototype, you really will like the full game (maybe wait for a sale, though).
If you expect another Hotline Miami, don't buy this. It loses all the chaotic energy of those games.
I will still be looking out for new games from this studio however; this gane seems more like the fumbling first steps than what the team could fully accomplish.

reviewText:
I‚Äôm all for innovation when it comes to blending genres to create something new and noteworthy, and SuperHot‚Äôs early prototype certainly had me intrigued when I first saw it. Never mind the strange, unseen narrator who references the game‚Äôs title ad nauseum or the shattering of red people like panes of glass, it was the nature of having a partial control of time while dodging bullets and dispensing your own in a slick, effortlessly stylish manner that sold me. The final product does deliver on its original proof of concept, but not without a few issues making things needlessly bothersome near the end.

Stand still and time moves at a crawl. Move or attack and time moves normally. This is the fundamental gimmick of SuperHot; making your character feel like a nigh-godly action hero who dispatches enemies effortlessly‚Ä¶ Except your character is made of even more fragile glass than the enemies. Enemies are killed instantly when they‚Äôre hit by a bullet, struck with a melee weapon or in seldom cases meet their demise via the environment, the exception being a three hit punch combo. You on the other hand can‚Äôt even take one punch without falling to the ground and dying horribly. Thus each level requires a chaotic ballet to avoid all sources of damage, otherwise you‚Äôre sent right back to the start of the level. Dying and restarting only takes a few seconds which is good since you‚Äôre likely to die on a constant basis while trying to figure out just the right way to tackle the opposition in front of you. Levels can be completed in multiple ways and styles, like throwing your empty gun at an enemy to stun him and grab the gun he drops so you can turn around and shoot down someone chasing you, then throw the new gun and beat the original enemy to death. Completing a level will have the game replay your endeavours in real time, making your assault look like one seamless act of quick thinking and fancy moves.

Often times there is a -lot- going on in SuperHot to track and manage in terms of threat to your livelihood, so thankfully the visuals have been designed to give players the best chance at survival. The world is shades of white and grey, enemies and their bullets trails are unmistakable red while weapons and bullets are an easily noticeable black. Even with the visuals being so clear on what‚Äôs a viable item for self-defense and what‚Äôs going to end you, it‚Äôs easy to move around or try to take a shot and get blindsided by a baseball bat upside the head or take a bullet in the back. Enemies have set spawns in the levels, so part of the challenge comes from knowing where to look and when - Spawn camping has never felt more justified. Of course there‚Äôs an incredible satisfaction in turning around quickly enough to see a bullet getting ready to pierce your ear only to calmly shuffle out of the way to avoid it, or being suppressed by an enemy with an assault rifle only to bob and weave past his stream of bullets and bop him in the mouth to disarm him.

While intercepting incoming bullets with your own or throwing a weapon at a slug to save yourself is a neat trick and all, there is a -very- rare but very bizarre case of your fired bullets and thrown weapons outright despawning when you look away. If you toss an empty pistol at an enemy only to look away to punch another, there‚Äôs a faint chance that the pistol will have completely disappeared by the time you look back. Combine this with slightly spotty hit detection when it comes to your character taking a fatal bullet or the range for melee strikes being unreliable with respect to whether you can actually strike even when the visual cue is active and later levels end up becoming far more tense and consequence ridden than I would‚Äôve liked. Despite there being a visual notification on enemies when you‚Äôre in melee range, attacking can end up with an embarrassing whiff and your character eating whatever punishment they have in mind, which is quite bad when you‚Äôre up against multiple enemies armed only with your fists and them with firearms.

The main campaign won‚Äôt take all that long even with repeated deaths, and the story that goes along with it can largely be discarded, but there are a few clever elements to the plot and how it interacts with the main menu, which emulates a DOS-style home computer that the player character is seated at. Completing the game unlocks speed run and survival modes along with special challenges which throw a wrench into the equation like having only a sword and no other weapons, or having your teleport ability (unlocked in the campaign) available from the start but  have your weapons limited to your fists which now instantly kill enemies. Although the majority of these modes take place in the campaign levels, being able to tackle old challenges with new tricks or handicaps can force new, clever strategies out of the player.

SuperHot doesn‚Äôt last all that long which is a shame for a game that uses such a great, slick gimmick. I‚Äôd argue that the game is a puzzler that just so happens to have guns in it, and after 3 hours I was disappointed that there wasn‚Äôt much else to solve excluding the unlocked bonus modes. Credit where due, the developer even decided to make a series of extra modes to extend game time and enjoyment of SuperHot, which would‚Äôve been a short one-trick-pony experience without. It‚Äôs a very cool game with a great series of mechanics that ends all too soon, but beyond that I can certainly recommend SuperHot for anyone who wants a combination of shooter and puzzle games that still brings something of its own to the table.

reviewText:
SUPERHOT is the most overpriced and pretentious game I've played in years.
This game has one thing going for it, and one thing only: time is bound to player movement. Is this innovative? Yes, absolutely. Is it hard to implement? No.
The graphics are simplistic with some nice particle effects, but that's s stylistic choice I will not hold against the game. What I will hold against it, however, is the bad quality of the models. Especially the assault rifle looks bad, and that's not a style choice, it simply looks horrible.
There is no music whatsoever except during the credits, I remember Kickstarter backers being promised the soundtrack - don't know where that went.
It's also incredibly overpriced, with 5-6 hours of playtime. The story consists of about 30 levels and takes you little more than 2 hours to beat. Then there are challenges, which simply are the story all over again with restrictions regarding your choice of weapons or how fast the ingame time flows and endless mode, which has all of its levels ripped out of the campaign. This is not worth the asking price.

What's worst about this is the incredible arrogance that the developers display. The game wants you to literally spam your friends with SUPERHOT is the most innovative shooter I've played in years". It also wants to be clever with useless
date: fourth-wall-and-immersion-breaking filler levels and simulated chatrooms
recommended: in which you have to mash buttons to "type".\n\nSave your money

reviewText:
Please do not buy this game. You would be supporting a new wave of disingenuous indie titles that seem cool, but provide very little in the way of value to the player.

------
edit: This sounds harsh, and I stand by it. I buried the main reason for this statement near the bottom under my criticism #4 so I wouldn't spoil the story right here. TLDR, bottom line, is that it feels like your money for this game is going primarily towards the development and maintenance of killstagram.com. You're paying a premium for the privilege to get your friends to also buy the game at its inflated price, and to me, it feels gross.
------

The gameplay mechanic, where time moves in super-slow-motion when you're not moving, is admittedly cool. Other neat things are the ASCII OS with phosphorous tint (which is used sometimes to render 3D scenes which looks pretty cool), and the shattering of red dudes when shot.

It becomes quickly apparent, however, that the game is very overpriced. The animations are poor (character movements remind me of Goldeneye, and the AI is about as advanced), weapon and object models are bland and blocky, and there are only three colors. Though these are obviously deliberate, designed aesthetic choices, as they often are with games made by small teams, normally those choices are for the benefit of other game elements.

edit: I did not make it clear that I do like the visual style--note that this is not one of my major criticisms of the game--read on.

However, it's difficult to ascertain what other game elements actually benefitted from these stylistic choices. My major criticisms:

1.  The game is painfully short, and it needs to be, because it gets boring to play towards the end.

The gameplay devolves into silly bullet-dodging crawls, which you usually need to start over numerous times. I often found myself dying simply because of the randomness of where the AI's shots went--sometimes there is no where to dodge to, sometimes you get just the window you need.

It's really a game of trial and error; simply not knowing that an enemy would spawn behind me at a particular point in time was pretty annoying too and hardly preventable, given the lack of auditory cues.

The game simply doesn't introduce new gameplay elements enough along the way, because there aren't many. You get one special ability towards the end--that's it.

2. Little variety in weapons: pistol, shotgun, assault rifle, katana. There are a few other melee weapons like baseball bats that function identically, I suppose. That's it.

By the way, the katana is not that fun to use: sliced red dudes always are cut through the waist or the neck. For some reason, no pure locational shatter model here--only when you throw it. Pretty disappointing short-cut.

3. Level design is at its best when it's completely derivative: the elevator, top of a train, cubicle farm, parking garage, subway, etc. You've seen all of this in movies.

There are only ever a few guys to deal with simultaneously, then the game starts pouring them out of different spawn points at different intervals. It's not so much of a puzzle game where it it is rewarding to figure out how to deal with a ton of enemies. Instead the game asks you instead to dispatch the enemies at the start as efficiently as possible so that you can deal with the new spawns in time.

The notion that speed is so important in a game designed around stopping time is kind of disappointing. It's not really there for you to stop and think as others have claimed--instead it's there for you to tip-toe around bullets and aim yours precisely. It's only about getting kills in as little real-time as possible--execution, not planning.

4. Its story isn't very unique, until you realize that it appears to be primarily a vehicle to recruit" you--essentially use you as an ad to sell more copies at its ridiculous price. While clever in how it breaks the fourth wall in this way and others
date: it added insult to injury for me
recommended: and simultaneously erased any probing thoughts or remaining questions I had about the story.\n\nSorry to spoil it
hoursPlayed: but the story doesn't have anything to say except "sell me." You only need to look at the positive reviews for this game to see what I mean.\n\n5. Tacked-on modes did little to alleviate the rest for me or add significant replay value. The only appealing challenge mode is a "katana-only" mode that appears to be mostly a replay of the story levels. Endless is exactly what you'd expect

reviewText:
GREAT GAME, ABYSMAL COLLISION DETECTION.

(You die when you shouldn't, enemies don't die when they should, and the environment has invisible extensions)

Firstly, let me say that SuperHot is actually a really good game. It‚Äôs unique, it‚Äôs innovative, and it‚Äôs damn good fun. The developers have a wonderful game idea here and they deserve our support for their work and for their achievement. I‚Äôm very happy to have supported SuperHot during its beta phase, and I‚Äôve already put in 11 hours of game time and with the possibility to invest many more hours into this brilliant twist on the first person shooter genre (depending on the devs course of action).

So, after all that praise, why am I not giving it a thumbs up? Simple: the game has some glaring faults that seriously interfere with enjoyment of the game, the worst of which is the collision detection. Let me explain...

Carefully lining up a shot so the bullet passes in between two shelved pieces of glassware thus hitting the red man behind them, the game instead decides to make the bullet collide with one of the glasses which then acts as a shield for the enemy. Said enemy then goes on to kill me because of the inaccuracy of my ‚Äúmissed shot‚Äù.
Conclusion: bad collision detection.

A thrown katana races elegantly towards the centre mass of a red man. Just as it's about to connect I feel pleased and confident with my well-aimed throw. The elated feeling, however, quickly turns to horror as I watch the sword touch the surface of my adversary and pass completely through the chest cavity with no effect whatsoever. I'm then unarmed and left at the mercy of a man wielding a rapidly-firing assault rifle.
Conclusion: appauling collision detection.

An enemy has fired a bullet at my head and I move out of the path of the bullet far enough for it to sail straight past me. Once I‚Äôve reached a safe distance from the trajectory of the incoming bullet I stop moving to slow down time to its minimum value so I can plan my counter attack strategy. While I‚Äôm standing there weighing up all of my options, the bullet gracefully glides through the air over towards the far left hand side of my screen. As the bullet is just about to pass me I‚Äôve made my decision for my counter offensive, and I‚Äôm about to put that plan into action when BAM - the stray bullet magically manages to hit my head despite me being nowhere near it. I then lose my 100 kill streak in endless mode and start muttering curse words under my breath.
Conclusion: really poor collision detection.

Sadly, these aren‚Äôt random occurances, as they‚Äôve happened to me many times during my 11 hours. It‚Äôs because of this sort of nonsense that I don‚Äôt play Battlefield 3 or 4 anymore. SuperHot's main fault is that it seems to treat your character as a human-sized cardboard box. An issue which needs fixing if people are to continue playing the game - and there are a lot of us with this grievance.

Very quickly, other collision issues include: bullets hitting walls even though the gun and the crosshairs are well away from them, and thrown weapons inexplicably exploding in mid air in front of you despite there being plenty of clearance for a successful weapon throw.

Another problem with which SuperHot suffers is a very short campaign. The game boasts having over 30 levels. The trouble is that most of these can be completed in about one minute - even on your first attempt. So a 30 level story mode took me just over an hour to complete leaving me sat there thinking, ‚ÄúWas that it?‚Äù
To make matters worse, these short levels are then punctuated with annoying story sequences that interfere with the flow of the levels and the action. However, it is worth noting that the vast majority of the enjoyable gameplay is to be found in the endless mode and the challenges - and these are genuinely fun. Manipulating the accelerating or deceleration of time by varying the velocity of your motion is a great bullet-time mechanic that allows you to overcome the odds despite your being outmanned and outgunned, and I have genuinely enjoyed the bug-free moments.

Pros:
- A really fun first person shooter with a unique mechanic that brings good puzzle work and strategy to the genre
- A lovely art style that dazzles the senses without ever cluttering up the screen
- Very nice sound effects that really immerse you in a world where bullet-time rules
- Watching red glass men crack, crumble, fall apart, and then disintegrate in front of you at what ever speed you choose is wonderfully entertaining

What we need from the devs:
- More levels
- A level editor so that the community can create and share its own maps and campaigns
- More variety in enemies and weapons to increase the game's longevity
- Greatly improved collision detection


I will be giving this review a thumbs up when and if the developers fix the game‚Äôs problems.

As always, leave your questions below and I‚Äôll get back to you.
Until then, I‚Äôll see you in the matrix...

reviewText:
Product received for free

https://youtu.be/qLO2HNQFMa4
Game: SUPERHOT
Genre: First-person Shooter
Developer: SUPERHOT Team
Publisher: SUPERHOT Team
Copy supplied by PCGN

SUPERHOT is a first-person shooter developed and published by SUPERHOT team. This is the indie darling of the year, and it deserves most of the praise that it is getting.

STORYThe plot follows the same gist of many meta-games: you are playing as someone playing SUPERHOT, and someone starts writing weird messages to you. If you are familiar with other games such as Pony Island, the game has some decent tricks up its sleave, but, unfortunately, it feels very derivative and not as smart as the aformentioned product.

GRAPHICSThe game has an interesting art-style: white environments with red enemies and black/blu-ish objects. It all looks very polished, but it got kinda old after a while. Thankfully, some Challenges change the color scheme, giving some much needed variety.

GAMEPLAYThe game is a first-person shooter where time moves only when you do, and later on you also unlock the ability to swap your body with an enemy's. This is done extremely well, and you can't but be amazed at how perfectly it was achieved by the developers. Bravo!
The only issue I have with the gameplay are the weapons: there are only a pistol, a double-barreled shotgun, a rifle and multiple melee weapons. But still, watching a real-time replay of what you just accomplished is very satisfying.

CHALLENGEDying with one hit makes the game very hard and quite frustrating in certain levels, but having more than one life would've trivialized the entire game. The AI is very smart and usually predicts where you are going to go, so that it can hit you always. After you got the hang on the controls, you can easily outsmart it, especially when knowing where enemies will spawn. The Challenges are also very fun to play, with different modifiers like Katana Only, Fists Only, Throws Kill and many more.

SOUNDThe soundtrack is your typical techno-pop music, and the sound effects are top notch, with sound warping when you move. The words said at the end of each level (SUPER HOT) are quite amusing at first, but they do get annoying after a while

REPLAYABILITYThe main game is very short: it took me under two hours to complete it. However, there are plenty more things to do that will keep you coming back more and more: Challenge mode, Endless mode, secret computers hidden in every level... A game musn't be criticised only for the lenght of the main story, but on the rest of the content as well. And here, there's plenty of fun to be had.

Overall, SUPERHOT is a very innovative and polished game that will appeal to most gamers. If you are here for the story, however, you will be disappointed by its short lenght and its expensive price. A must-buy when at 15$.

This is my first ever review so sorry for any misinterpretations and or spelling errors.

Starting off with what everyone has said, yes... the campaign in it's own right isn't very long, ranging from 2-3 hours depending on how you tackle the game.

However, the challenges in their own right will provide for a longer game, for me it added roughly 5 hours, almost 2 or 3 hours exclusively on the norestart mode, which means you have to beat the whole game (all levels except level 26) without dying once.

This game also brings in a few unique gameplay mechanics. Slow time, differential mental spaciation (taking control of others put in a more simple way) and bhop utilization (bunny-hopping).

If you are like me and like to fully complete games via achievements, then this game is for you. Albeit, it comes at a challenge, but overall I would say the game is both fun and challenging, providing for a great experience.

TLDR: 1. Game is fun
2. Initial campaign is short, but with added challenges and endless mode, it makes up for quite a number of hours of gameplay.
3. Game can be 100% (perfected) if you are dedicated, but it will provide a challenge (which in my opinion is good).

reviewText:
First of all, the game is very short, so if you're looking for something with a story-mode that you can play for 5+ hours, this most likely won't be it. I finished it in one session, probably around 2-3 hours, and I wasn't in a rush doing so.

But beyond that, it's such a enjoyable game and the most fun I've had with a FPS in a long while. The concept of time only moving when you do (including moving to look around, clicking prematurely and missing a shot/punch, and etc.) is very simple but done well. For those that care about the story, you'll find a strange but creative plot to follow, and for people that just want to shoot a bunch of red dudes, nothing is stopping you from just doing that.

The level design is unique for each stage, and for the majority of it, it seems fair and fun to move your way through it like a puzzle. A few levels did have issues with starting you too close to enemies and the randomness of their shots sometimes making it tougher than it should, but overall once you learn how to play with the mechanics it isn't too difficult for anyone that normally plays FPS games.

Importantly, just shooting things feels good, seeing them explode into a bunch of shards everywhere. Swords slice through enemies in a very gratifying way, shotguns feel good just to aim into a room and watch a ton of pellets fly everywhere in slow motion, and even throwing a pool ball across the room and smacking a guy in the head with it is an awesome feeling.

Overall get this game if you don't mind spending the cash for a short game, though the experience condensed in two hours is better than what you'd get for a lot of games in 10+ hours. There's replay value for speedrunning, finding secrets, and other modes unlocked upon beating the game, or just self-imposed challanges like melee only. I'd wait for it to go on sale personally or find somewhere cheaper (30$ is a bit steep in my opinion), but definitely pick it up at some point.

EDIT: Playing about 25 hours more, the game has a lot to play than I gave it credit for. Not all the challenges are different and unique, but most are fun and make you play the game in ways you hadn't before. Endless mode is also a cool mode, and there's a good variety of maps and gamemodes with that as well, but there's no motivation not to camp in a room with one entrance and play that way to get a good score, though that doesn't take away the fun of it. Speedrunning the game is really fun as well (not just the mode, but doing actual full-game runs) and the community surrounding it have been nothing but helpful when I've talked to them.

reviewText:
Review originally posted on Vox Ludicus - Review: Superhot[voxludicus.wordpress.com]

‚ÄúWe could keep you here forever‚Äù is one of the many prompts that the system displays during your bullet-ridden romp through the digital world in Superhot. Developed by the SuperHot Team, this is a first person game with a peculiar twist: time only moves when you do. This allows for some intense sequences where you kill multiple enemies while bullets and limbs whiz past you, and it feels very satisfying to clear an entire level after rampaging through the room and killing half a dozen enemies. I now know what Ryan Reynolds felt like in that masterpiece of a superhero movie, Green Lantern.

The first thing you notice after you boot up the game is the graphics and presentation: the menu is presented as a computer terminal, and the narrative is often delivered in the form of one of those old IRC chat rooms. The enemies - red, polygonal humanoids - explode into small crystals when killed, and the lack of a HUD adds to the game's immersion by making it look like you're in an action movie's trailer. Sound design remains minimalist, and you will only hear a few different effects throughout the game, such as the hollow 'click' as the gun you are holding is empty and the obnoxiously loud 'SUPERHOT SUPERHOT SUPERHOT' at the end of each level.

The game's crown jewel is, evidently, the gameplay. The levels themselves are not overtly challenging, the enemies normally coming from all around you, converging on you like the hired thugs on a D list action movie, and while they all die with one bullet so do you. This means you need to be constantly on the move in order to avoid a hail of bullets and pre-empt the enemy movements in order to shoot them successfully. The final few levels do allow you to ''superswitch'' and control an enemy's body, but this does little to change the game's flow.

The story itself is quite straightforward, just like a binding road. It seems quite clear at the start but turns into quite a mess - that said, the story is never at the forefront of the game, and instead takes a back seat to the gameplay. It is important to keep in mind that each level does contain ''secrets'' or items hidden in obscure areas of the levels that offer an insight into the story for those brave adventurers who stray off the beaten path. However, these secret items are not necessary to complete the story mode and consequently, the story mode is able to be completed in just under 2 hours.

Once you complete the game's story mode, the challenge and endless mode are unlocked, from which most of the additional replay value comes from. The challenges offer a variety of different elements such as only using katanas, and there are also speed runs in which you must race the clock to complete a level, although this added replay value is only present for as long as the tight gameplay entices you.

Overall, the game is definitely innovative and utilizes an interesting and refreshing mechanic. It is a blast to romp through the game's 2 hour story mode but this may be the game's weakest point - given the price, some might feel the price tag to be a bit on the salty side of things. While there are challenges to complete afterwards, they can get quite repetitive after a short amount of time and things could've easily been enhanced by the presence of a level editor. A fun, albeit short, game.

reviewText:
The first thing that struck me about super hot is the minimal graphics, they're stunningly vivid, and at the same time, have the feeling that their purpose is primarily functional.
I have sunk too many hours into this game. Its story is very short, but what super hot offers is addictive, and challenging. The story is easy enough, but racking up giant scores in the endless mode is where I found the most fun. And watching the real time replay is remeniscient of a fast paced matrix loby scene.
The story, though short, encapsulates an amazing tone and emotion for the game. I won't spoil specifics, but it held my attention until it was over, and then opened up a range of challenges that I was itching to tackle.
For me, the $25 price tag wasn't too much, because it combined my favorite aspects of my favorite action games, and left me thinking, while repeating the game's title over and over again in my head. If you're on the fence, or only looking to complete the story, You may want to wait for a sale.

reviewText:
When I got this game, I absolutely loved it. The feeling of snatching a gun out of someone's grip, spinning around and blasting the guy behind you, tossing the weapon at another guy, possessing him, grabbing the weapon and shooting your old body is amazingly cool!

However...

It turns out that I was experiencing a bug which drastically slowed down the game, making your movements and the physics happen much more slowly. It was all still proportional, because everything moved slower. The latest update fixed this, making the game much faster.

It also made the game suck.

Beforehand, it had the feel of a puzzle game. Minor adjustments were the difference between life and death. You still felt like a major badass, but actually playing the game felt like a cerebral challenge, as you could see certain things (i.e enemy shots) lining up before they happened. This lead to some insanely cool moments, like when I just managed to dodge two assault rifle bursts whilst running down a hallway, and timed my katana throw perfectly so that it killed one of the guys just as his own bullet killed his friend. Now, that feeling is gone as each level basically becomes a massive spaz out where all the time to think is gone, and death comes from behind constantly. It's just not fun.

I feel stupid now, because if I'd known this is how the game actually ran, I would have refunded it straight away, or not bothered to buy it. Now it's too late, and I'm stuck with a game I hate and ¬£17 or so quid down.

TL;DR : Game was fun when bugged, now it's fixed and it plays like ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•.

reviewText:
I don't really write reviews for games but I feel like I should write one for this, specifically since it is in Early Access.

Yes, the story is very short, unfortunately. I completed it in about 2 hours, with messing around in the campaign (Trying dumb stuff, no slow mo, etc). While it is a pretty dark and good story (If you want to call it a story, more like a stretched plotline to a story), there really isn't much to it.

After beating the story you get Challenge Mode, and Endless Mode. Challenge Mode being the single player campaign with certain restrictions or objectives to meet, Endless Mode being exactly that. endless enemies spawning in an arena. The more you play, the more arenas you unlock. It can get boring after a while but I can see myself always coming back for at least a little fun for quite some time in the future.

The game itself, however, is fantastic. It even came with it's own website, where you can upload your own clips and replays. While even that may not be handling all the traffic it's been getting, not many games have that. I do wish there were more edit options, however.

Time moving only when you move is a great concept. Any action, even rotating, allows things to move. You can chain together kills in a very satisfying way and put together combos that make you look like you've played shooters every day for your entire life. The game flows extremely smooth and I can't help but say the only reason it wasn't worth the 20 dollars is because the story is so short. But I'm sure more content will be added in future patches, so eventually it will be worth the 20. 15? Sure, but personally I think 10 is too low.

With the popularity this has gotten in only a few days time, there is bound to be more content added (hopefully some *background music*) and eventually, I would hope, mod support. Community levels I would imagine is the minimum that will come into play.

Play this game, tell people to play this game, share it with your friends.
But don't talk too much about it, don't let them know what the system is about.

reviewText:
SUPERHOT is a game that starts out with a videodrome-like plot built around simple gameplay, a lot like the Jacob's Ladder experience that was Pony Island.

But whereas Pony Island was more about the strange twists things took, Superhot's shorter simpler plot arc doesn't do much more than act as bumpers for the gameplay, and is ultimately an unsatisfying narrative.

But what great gameplay!  The real 'meat' of the game actually starts AFTER you finish the main story and start working through the challenges and endless mode.  In fact, the main reason for anyone to buy this game in my view is that it will help train your quick-thinking skills - this game is a wonderful 'workout' for your nervous system when you get into it!

When you do get far into the challenges, you will find yourself going into 'the zone' an awful lot, and pulling off amazing combos at near-realtime.  It's extraordinarily satisfying and great fun when you do.  This game and its challenge modes warrant multiple playthroughs in my view, to keep training your skill and improving what combos you can pull off.

PROS
-Fantastic core gameplay built around a simple well-done premise
-Trains your quick-thinking strategic skills and reflexes
-You can see yourself physically getting better as you tend to play more in 'real time' as you get better
-Some interesting little side-gimmicks
-A uniquely surreal and bleak sense of humor
-Pretty to look at for such simple graphics, and very nice sound design
-Challenges and endless mode are the real 'meat' of the game, and fantastic satisfying fun

CONS
-Gameplay could have been developed and expanded upon much more than it was (more enemy types, more weapon variety, more gameplay twists than just bodyswapping, more level scenarios pushing what you can do)
-Some minor annoyance with some melee attacks not quite connecting in spite of swinging close
-Weak and altogether too short story

Overall: 8/10 - With the asterisk that I feel this is a 'must-buy' for anyone who fancies themselves and esports player. This is a game you can play on your downtime to train your reflexes or warm up your quick-thinking skills.  Additionally I would bump this to 9/10 if post-launch sees free updates with additional content.

reviewText:
Hey folks MrChimp here, I recently sat down and played SUPERHOT on my stream which usually runs for about 2 hours a night 3 nights a week. Thinking this game looks great I will get my two hours in and call it good. That didn‚Äôt happen. Once I was in the game had me reeled in and I could not put it down. Played through the entire story mode in one sitting and started to pick at endless mode and challenges after that.

SUPERHOT just throws your right into the action with its intuitive controls and addicting game play. You start out just killing red dudes because they want to kill you and then your roped into this swirling story that leaves you wonder ‚ÄúWhat the hell is going on?‚Äù and you keep wanting more, you become a slave to the system until it ‚ÄúFrees‚Äù you.

This game has a ton of replay ability built in with 100ish challenge to complete and many levels of endless madness after the campaign. The mechanic that this game is made on is truly one of a kind! Time only moves when you move so you find yourself jumping into a level and getting into it then dying, trying a couple more times. After a bit you get the pattern down and start working on a path to victory but the great thing is every playthrough is different based on how you move through the map.

The graphic style is great, and it's one that could run on practically any system. The game play is seamless and enjoyable. I cannot leave out the awesome soundtrack as well.

In closing I would give this game 10/10 and would recommend it to anyone that wants a challenging game that they can pick up and play without too much set up or grinding. All you have to do is enter the system and start killing red dudes.

I hope you enjoyed the review as much as I enjoyed playing the game! If it was helpful or this review needs work please let me know in the comments!

reviewText:
A Filipino Review of SUPERHOT


Just before I start my pros and cons, know that I played the ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• out of the initial protype/beta that they put out. I exhausted the gameplay to the point that my initial addiction it waned and the only thing that I was hyped about was the story. The prototype (which took me 2 hours to beat, as I died repeatedly) ended with a cliffhanger.

Pros

Unique Bullet Time mechanic
(As of this writing) plenty of unsolved secrets
Plenty of modes and challenges after completion of the initial story
A unique story
Cons

Provided you don't die a lot, the campaign can be completed around 90 minutes.
The gameplay is the only thing that holds it, don't expect anything more.
The price tag
I'll just say this off the bat, I liked the game. I really do. The story drew me in and in my own opinion, it had a good ending. The gameplay in the game is one of a kind, there is no game like it.

BUT, it's asking price of around PHP500+ and it's apparent $20+ price tag in the West is too much. The campaign is far too short for the asking price. Though there are challenges, easter eggs and an endless mode; which add a certain sense of replayability, once the glamour of the gameplay wears off, there's not much left in the game.

So as much as it pains me, I refunded the game. I spent 90 minutes on the campaign and an additional 30 minutes on the challenges, but I got bored quickly.

1) Buy it now
2) Wait for a sale
3) Wait for a BIG DISCOUNT when it's on sale
4) Don't touch it

The game deserves your money, but not the price it's asking.

reviewText: It's the most innovative shooter I've played in years!"\n\nYou've probably read that line a few times if you've read anything at all about SUPERHOT. And it would be correct. date:

reviewText:
SUPERHOT is an awesome mix of a first person shooter with puzzle-like elements. This game is unforgiving with every wrong move but when you succeed and finally complete a level its extremely satisfying. It also includes a replay feature where you can save and upload all of your replays after completing a mission to their website killstagram.com which seems to currently be in the beta stages.


The story is also fairly unique and the way they execute it is quite genius for the type of game it is (for example, the game will tell you to leave, and glitch out forcing you to exit the game). The game plays tricks on your mind as you navigate through the world not knowing whats next. It feels like you're playing virual reality while stuck in the matrix. Time moves when you do allowing you to plot your next move but if you move in the wrong direction or waste too much time, youre dead and have to start the level over again.


SUPERHOT is really different from any other game I have ever played and has plenty of replay value with its Endless Modes and Challenges. I highly recommend this game, although the price tag is fairly steep I would suggest looking for it cheaper elseware.

reviewText:
This is going to hold a record for the highest reviewed game with the most refunds.

You really can't say a bad thing about the gameplay. It's a simple, fun game that makes you feel like an action hero. You'll use anything you can to kill your enemies and while dodging bullets in slow motion and you'll feel like a bad-‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• doing it.

I would imagine most people are going to feel ripped off at its current $22.49 pricetag. The main game took me 90 minutes to finish and there is very little replay value. You unlock endless mode and a challenge mode but I have no interest in either. Buy it when it drops to your personal price for 90 minutes of entertainment or hope that someone buys it for you.

reviewText:
Not worth the asking price.

What I played was promising but I was pretty let down.

I agree that the time stopping mechanic is both cool and fun, but the mere five weapons and one enemy type really doesn't cut it for me, particularly with the short length of the game and asking price of $35(!) Canadian.

The lack of a soundtrack is a stylistic choice, but not one I agree with. I feel like having music that was slowed down with the time stops would have added to the experience.


It's not unenjoyable, but it feels like you're paying a whole lot of money for an early access game that isn't going to get finished. You could do worse with your money than SUPERHOT but it really could have been more.

reviewText:
PROS: Amazing concept, the game also look very polished. The story is there to introduce you to the basics, and is a mix between 1984 and The Matrix.

MID: The fact that you can complete the actual story under 2 hours without tryharding isn't really what bothers me. Endless mode and challenges are here to keep you entertained, plus the game got tons of secret and hidden content.
The price tag ? It was the same when I bought it in beta, over a year ago. Would I buy it now, at this price, for this content, if I haden't before ? Probably not. On sale would be better.

CONS: Poorly optimized. The beta already suffered from this, but I can't believe the game still manages to stutter so much. Frame drops, freezes, specially shapes-filled situations. Moreover, all of this still happens on lowest settings, and on a high-end gaming PC.

Overall, the game is great, the concept is great, but as of right now it needs some love and some testing in order to be really great, so i wouldn't recommend buying it at full price.

1) Stay away
2) Only recommended when on sale
3) Recommended
4) Highly recommended
5) This is a must play
