reviewText:
Fantastically polished game, SUPERHOT takes the prototype and does an excellent job of developing the mechanics in to a finalised product that's worth every penny.

SUPERHOT has a very simple ruleset, and equally simple (but effective) visuals to accommodate that. As a result it's always very clear what you're supposed to be doing. While it is an FPS game, the core mechanic turns it in to something much more strategy-based, especially when attempting the challenge modes.

The main criticism people have with the game is that it's too short, and that's true if you ignore all the extra content that comes after completing the story mode. If you're somebody that enjoys challenging yourself, then you'll have many hours of fun with the challenge modes, in that respect the story mode is more like a long tutorial.

My only personal gripe is that the boss character featured in the prototype didn't make an appearance, but understandably they decided to take the game in a different direction.

In short, if you like the look of this and you understand that the story mode is only a small portion of the game, then I absolutely recommend it.

I honestly cannot recommend SUPERHOT to more people than I can right now. There is nothing more satifiying than watching all the cool ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• you did during a level in real time and getting to easily save and upload it to view over and over again. The improvements to the game with the Throwable weaponry and varied weapons add more depth to the game and once the Switch Mechanic comes into play you can do some very clever stuff.

The challenges range from enjoyable nostalgia romps to frantic perfection to pure agonising frustration and give a nice depth of post game. The endless modes can be a barrel of fun to just casually slaughter everything and overall all the little details really make the game stand out. On top of that the fact that you can give friends discount codes for the game when you beat it is a very nice touch

Personally I think that maybe ¬£17.99 is a bit of a steep asking price and the main story being a bit short is a shame but if you have enough money to consider it I'd honestly say it's worth the experience. Overall a very solid game mechanic that innovates in it's field 8.7/10 from me.

reviewText:
SUPER. HOT... SUPER. HOT... SUPER. HOT... SUPER. HOT... SUPER. HOT... SUPER. HOT...

--------------------------

IN ALL SERIOUSNESS:
This game is INCREDIBLE. 9/10.
My one gripe with this game is its price, though. $25US is a very high price for a game with a 2 hour story. Although the endless mode is incredible too, there just isn't enough content to justify it in my own eyes. Mind you, im a binge gamer so maybe I'm not the best to judge.
As far as sound goes, the slow-motion and speed up sound effects works perfectly. The DOS Operating System-esk theme with the UI and loading screen sounds nostalgic to say the least.
In terms of graphics I experienced minor frame drops for no apparent reason and the game would only start on my second monitor. However these 2 things are not enough for me to think less of this game. It is incredible.
Gameplay is the key feature of this game. The whole time-moves-when-you-move concept is captivating, creating a mechanic that never ceses to amaze. But I can't express in words just how it works and why it's incredible. Total Biscuit made a WTF IS video about it here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=AJVrquYvGRA and it's available (obviously) on steam for you to buy if you have the spare cash.
Story: I was shaking. It is actually quite overwhelming how this game can capture you, albeit it is quite short. The ending: Award worthy. Go play it.
I'm not revealing much as I feel it is something that can't be expressed through text, but through actually playing the game and frankly I dont have the time to write an essay. Have fun guys!

reviewText:
This game is great.  What a breath of fresh air.  The base gameplay feels like nothing else I've ever played.  This is action that has all kinds of craziness to it at a pace that is slowed down a little bit more than enough to barely be able to deal with it all.  Time only moves when you do, but you're still under constant pressure and constant fire.  Throwing guns at people to take their other guns from them, dodging bullets, grabbing a telephone and whipping it at the incoming bullets to destroy that oncoming shotgun blast, switching bodies to the guy behind the machine gunner giving you trouble and punching him in the head, etc etc etc..

The campaign is great, but it's just the warm-up.  Once it is completed there are Endless modes and Challenges to complete and unlock.  The first to unlock is a Katana-Only set of what you already know, but you're unable to use anything but the Katana you started with.  Switches up every strategy I had formed prior.  I found myself learning new tricks the whole way.  My friends and I have been switching off every couple runs in an attempt to unlock everything and even after 13 hours we still haven't unlocked it all yet.

There's a couple minigames hiding in here, like Tree Dude, which can be fun if you're in the mood for something simple.

I don't think the price is too high, and I don't think the campaign is too short (since it's really just at tutorial, sort of).  This the most innovative shooter I've played in years!

reviewText:
SUPERHOT is ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing bonkers. SUPERHOT would be a Jackie Chan movie, if Jackie Chan was really into cyberpunk and had seen The Matrix a thousand times. It's a game where you beat up a dude in a bathroom stall, then you pick up the bottle in the corner of the restroom, use it to glass the face of the red dude coming in for a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, and after all that, you see the bartender with his shotgun in his hands, and you dare to pick up one of the billard balls on the pool table, and then you dare even harder to chuck it at his ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing head. It's ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing wonderful improvisation combat in the form of a puzzle FPS.

The game does a fantastic job telling you all the basics without having to explain it to you through its use of colors and visual language. The scenery is white-grey, things you kill with are colored black, red dudes are bad and must be punished, use black things to kill red dudes. Even if you haven't played many FPS games, you'll know instantly what's going on, allowing you to focus on the puzzle side of the game - the puzzle of how you kill those red dudes. And even then, the game manages to pull out some novel takes on its formula - the Elevator Pitch level is a ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing great take on using your fists to get the upper hand on three people with guns pointed at you point-blank.

Some whiners say that the three-hour campaign is too little story for $25. But they're also ignoring the wealth of challenges, the Endless mode, and the various secrets built into the game. And even if we're judging the game entirely by its entire campaign - SUPERHOT has a really well done, solid campaign, one that hits its mark, never misses a beat, and knows exactly where to start and when to quit. I'd rather have a campaign that is three hours long, artfully paced, knowing how best to deliver its thrills, and is concluded properly rather than a campaign that takes fifteen hours, wears out its welcome, and farts out a conclusion that makes me never want to play the game again after I'm done. Have we learned nothing from ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•ing Portal, a game that is almost flawless and just two hours long? Meeting an arbitrary goal of how much time your game consumes does not make a game good.

The only real complaint I have is that I don't know if the stuff between the campaign levels is going to hold up for me down the line? I imagine myself old and toothless, and I'll scream WHAT IS THIS DOS ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•, I NEED TO KILL THE RED PEOPLE. And then I'll throw my cellphone at the TV and have to be sent to work in the salt mines on the Plutonian Asteroid and Old Folks' Home. Being old is going to suck, but at least I'll always have Superhot!

reviewText:
IT'S THE MOST INNOVATIVE SHOOTER I'VE PLAYED IN YEARS
Now that I've gotten that obligation out of the way, SUPERHOT is a short but sweet game centered around the premise of time manipulation in a first-person shooter. If you haven't played the free demo that's been floating around online for the last couple years, you should probably play it, as that will determine whether or not you'll like this game.

There's an overall narrative similar to Pony Island, if you've played it. Basically, you're thrown from stage to stage with the objective of killing all the red guys. They'll be equipped with their fists, pistols, shotguns, machine guns, etc... And you'll be using time manipulation to deal with all of them. They take one hit (3 with fists or thrown objects) to kill, and so do you. If you die at any point during one of the many brief stages, you'll be thrown back to the beginning of that stage to learn from your mistakes, and try again, eventually defeating all of your foes, and moving onto the next stage.

The main story mission takes about 90 minutes to complete, give or take a little based on your ability to grasp the time manipulation concept.

Once you're finished with the main story mission, you'll be provided with access to all 32 missions you previously completed, endless mode, and some challenges.

Endless mode is a whole bunch of levels from the story mode where the overall goal in each level is to kill as many enemies as you possibly can, allowing you to unlock even more levels in this mode. This is probably the mode that most of your money is going toward, as it seems to provide the most content out of anything in the game. So before somebody tries to persuade you that the game is too expensive for a 2 hour (or 90 minute in my case) campaign, they probably didn't try out endless mode.

Challenges are unlocked by accomplishing certain tasks throughout the story mode's missions, and once a challenge is unlocked, it will unlock a new mode for all of the main story missions, such as a speed run mode, or a speed run mode with a timer that counts down even when you're not moving. Not quite sure what all the other modes are, as I haven't unlocked them yet. There's 13 in total. Besides the two speedrun ones I have, there's also one where you only have a katana.

Beyond the main time manipulation game, you can also navigate the game's unique main menu to find some other various mini-games and fun bonus content.

I've seen the pricing for this game compared to something like Firewatch, but in the end, both games are around the same length, except Firewatch doesn't have any endgame content, and frankly SUPERHOT's story is more interesting.

Pros    Unique time manipulation mechanic for an FPS.
Unique graphics, combined with interesting UI that makes for an interesting narrative similar to Pony Island.
A lot more bang for your buck that I would have initially expected based on the demo that released however many years ago.
Dodging enemy bullets can get really fun, especially when you realize that they tend to lead their shots, so strafing in one direction is generally not the best decision.
Neat mechanic introduced late into the game that I'd rather not spoil here. It's used in endless mode though. Really cool feature in the game that I wasn't expecting.
The story mission levels are based around action scenes in popular films.
When you finish a level in any mode, you get to watch and edit the full-speed version of the entire level's gameplay footage from your perspective. That means none of the time manipulation stops, so you get to look like you're even better at first-person shooters than you really are. Clips can be edited and uploaded straight to a website called Killstagram too.
SUPERHOT SUPERHOT SUPERHOT
Cons    For a game that touts an endless mode based around high scores, there's no online leaderboards, at least at launch that is. I have no idea if the devs plan on adding them in post-launch or something, but as it is, you kill as many baddies as possible in a level, and then when you die, it saves that score, and you can view it from the level select screen as your Personal High Score". Kind of makes trying to achieve high scores not as much of a thrill when you're competing with yourself.
Endless mode levels are also unlocked based on overall kills in that level

reviewText:
The basic premise is a friend of yours finds a crack to a new video game and sends it to your computer.
I guess I could define it as a time based, first person shooter...
But, that wouldn't be exactly correct.
I could say it's a puzzle game disguised as a shooter, but that would leave out the time dilation, hacking, amazing ballistics simulation, and of course... things... things I can't tell you.
SuperHot is something that has to be experienced first hand.
What you see and do is not going to be the same as you would think you would do.
The cool thing about SuperHot is you don't realize there is a deeper story unless you dig for it.
Yes SuperHot has shooting, it has time based movement,
it has puzzles, semi-hacking and unique graphics that are freaky mixture of ASCII text and modern-gen effects.
SuperHot can be brutally difficult at times as well.
Other times, it can seem to easy. Once you learn the best way to attack, some weapons can feel too overpowered while others are pretty worthless.
The AI will run you down and will fire off that fatal shot just one micro-second before you were going to blast that red dude down with some buckshot.
In fairness I can not fully review this game, because doing so would give too much of the experience away.
If you like shooters mixed with cool retro vibe and some conspiracy theory mixed in, SuperHot should be right up your alley.
The game is very polished, runs great and is a pleasure to play.
This is a thinking person's game though.
Don't expect to charge head on to the enemy blasting away. You have to pick your moments of attack, all the while keeping your head on a 360 degree swivel for that sneaky ‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô•‚ô• that will come up behind you.
Usually if you hear a gunshot from a new direction that you are unaware of, you are already dead. The difficulty is fair as can be though. Nothing happens in the world until you move.
Bad guy standing right in front of you with a machine gun?
He will not move or fire an inch until you do (Well, he will but very, very slowly).
This gives you tactical time to think of the best course of action.
Moving quickly will only get you killed faster. Take your time and think out your options. Sometimes the best option is a punch to the face.
Here is an example of a level:
I start out with no weapons. A man is in front of me with a baseball bat. He is very, very slowly running toward me.
I wait until he is in reach and punch him. As he is knocked back I grab the baseball bat that gets thrown from his grip.
Spinning around I see another guy with his bat halfway through the arc to bash in my brains, I gut him with my bat and continue spinning around to the first guy who is starting to recover from my punch.
I smash him in the head and move forward.
Now I see a guy coming down a hallway with a pistol. He runs toward me as I dart between pillars. When he comes around the corner to shoot at me I smash his hand with my bat and grab his gun from the air while tossing my bat at his face.
I spin around again and pop a shot into the knees of the other bat boy who was right behind me. I hear a boom and see red tracers flying through the air at the spot I was just 1 second ago.
Another unseen doorway had opened with another guy with a shotgun. I raise my gun up and fire off a round but by the time the bullet reaches him he has already moved in another direction.
Got him now... click... click... click. No!, my gun is empty!
He is only 4 feet from me now and is raising the shotgun up to eye level.
I panic and throw the pistol at him.
The pistol hits him just as he fires.
The bullets from his shotgun are too close for me to dodge and I go down at the same time screaming NOOOOOO!
SUPERHOT!
If that doesn't get your blood pumping, then you need to have your pulse checked.

SuperHot - 7 out of 10 Total

Graphics:	8 / 10
Graphically this game looks good for what it is.
There are basically three colors in the world.
White, Red and Black. However, the way the graphics are presented
and the smooth framerate more than make up for more realistic looking graphics.

Gameplay:	  7.5 / 10
Gunplay is pretty solid, other than the annoyance of waiting for the next bullet in the clip to be ready (my biggest gaming gripe about this game), but I see why they did it from a gameplay point of view. Katanas feel especially powerful, with being able to cut a guy in half with one swipe and even chop bullets in half mid-flight.

Story:  7 / 10
The story as such starts out typical of a guy being excited for a new game and slowly ratchets up to something unexpected and different. While not the most engaging story (not any character development, drama or comedy), this story is all about mystery and excitement and does a fine job with just that.

Audio:  8 / 10
Does the job. Nothing amazing but no problems either.

PC Options:  6 / 10
No real options other than default stuff like resolution, Windowed mode and 2 or 3 small things. Would have liked to see some neat features like different color shaders and the like.

Price:  6 / 10
The price at release is the biggest problem I have.
The game is good. The game does what it says on the tin.
However, the lack of variety of gameplay and rather short story mode really bring this score down. If it was $15 rather than $25 I would have no issues with the price.

Final Word:
While SuperHot's main story mode is rather short,  it makes up for it with extra modes like Endless Mode and Challenges that open up after the main game finishes. If you are looking for an interesting take on a bad guy vs good guy shooter without a lot of dialogue or missions, other than to kill the red guys, then SuperHot might be worth checking out.
If you can wait for a sale, I would wait for the $15 to $20 price point. If you follow my twitter @jdwohlever message me and I'll send you a coupon code for 15% off while supplies last.

reviewText:
In SUPERHOT, you control time! It's more of puzzle game than a FPS though because you need to have patience to plan your movements. If you rush in, you will likely die. When you stop moving, time nearly haults as well. You can use this time manipulation to dodge bullets, narrowly avoiding death as you destroy all of the enemies in each level. Throw weapons or various objects to block bullets and disarm your enemies, hot switch to change places with one of your enemies, leaving them to die instead of you.

Please check out my Quick Review Video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=5ViYBuzR0ac
Pros:
-interesting and intriguing story (it took me about 3.5 hours for the main story)
-awesome, fun, and unique gameplay
-lots of content after the main story (different challenges, time trials, endless modes)
-easy to upload and share your replays to Superhot's killstagram.com right in the game

Cons:
-not a whole lot of menu options (lacks fullscreen windows, controls)
-SUPER HOT repeating voice gets annoying after each level

Overall, the story was well done, and the gameplay was very enjoyable. This game has a lot to offer, and you can pull off some really crazy plays. If you enjoy challenge modes, timed modes, and/or endless modes, this game is certainly worth the full price. However, if you intend to play ONLY the main story, I suggest waiting for a sale.

reviewText:
A breath of fresh air for FPS.
I have been following this game for some time, since it was first shown as a Game Jam '14 entry. Instantly I thought it looked very interesting and fun. Now that the game is released and modestly fleshed out, I have to admit, I LOVE it!!

So the main mechanic is the speed of time. When you are not moving, it moves SUPER slow. When you look around, it speeds up a little. Finally, when you move, it goes into normal speed. Your object is to kill the enemies utilising these mechanics without eating a bullet, fist or blade first. It sounds simple but it is almost like a puzzle game at times when you need to figure out the order of your actions otherwise you die. You can punch dudes, grab their guns and shoot them in the head and then throw the empty gun at someone to stun them, allowing you to move in for the kill. It's great fun and SUPER satisfying.

The story" is not too long and seems to be the main complaint amongst folk. Depending on your skill level
date: it can be done within a few hours. However
recommended: the game then has challenge modes which have certain criteria such as running through the levels again allowing throwing items only
